/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hmm, need to fix the protocol too
Revived because I'm fed up of tunnelling to get to prometheus alertmanager address when clicking on URL from an alert (and probably there's more of fed up people).

Skimmed the docs and code, and the ONLY place where this is used is the JSON body sent to a web hook (docs: https://prometheus.io/docs/alerting/latest/configuration/#webhook_config).

@Doug - do you still oppose, or are you fine with changing the default of the backlink url on web hook sent content?
Had a discussion with Doug, he still thinks changing the default is not a good idea, let's go with not changing the default.
If there is no compelling reason to change the default - which I haven't seen -, then the current solution seems reasonable.
Please share the reasoning. Others would like to know too. ;-)
Since there's only one bug related to this, and nobody else have complained - let's leave the default and allow users to change it if they need to.

ansible/roles/prometheus/templates/prome.message:
Should we define `prometheus_alertmanager_external_url` to allow people to change the behaviour via an override? Just thinking that some people might legitimately rely on accessing it via the internal VIP and this patch would break that workflow?

Note that Prometheus server continues to use the internal URL - we could cover that at the same time?

https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blame/master/ansible/roles/prometheus/templates/prometheus-server.json.j2#L2
If we change the default it could break links in peoples existing notifications. I'm happy to be convinced, but I don't see a strong reason to change it.

I think external in this case, just means behind a proxy.

If I understand correctly, by changing to the external VIP, we risk 'breaking' anyone currently accessing the Alertmanager UI via the internal VIP.

I think the bug is really that we should be able to choose whether we pass the external, or internal VIP to Alertmanager as the 'external' URL. Both are valid use cases IMO.

I think we should maintain the status-quo as a default, at least when backporting, because there is a real risk breaking peoples existing workflows.
Changing --web.external-url argument does not prevent from serving requests via internal VIP. It's value is merely a hint to Alertmanager for building backlink URLs in alert notifications.

> Doug, Piotr already explained where is this used and why it should be external.

I respectfully disagree here - please see my earlier comments.
Ok then, let's introduce a new variable with defaulting to as-it-is-today on stable branches and change the default on master?
Actually, I just noticed that Prometheus server is only exposed internally, so we can leave that.

I think that if the cmdline variable is called web.external-url, then it should point to an externally accessible url - I don't think we'll break anybody with that. If we will - they should raise a bug and introduce a new variable?
Your disagreement has been noted, let's wait for other reviews.

Doug, Piotr already explained where is this used and why it should be external. I understand that we don't want to break existing deployments, that's why we will change the default in master (+reno) and backport this additional variable without changing the default.

Second thing is, that we probably would prefer to introduce a prometheus_alertmanager_external_fqdn variable (as it's done in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/823395).

Piotr please propose a new version taking my notes in consideration - thanks.

> Should we define `prometheus_alertmanager_external_url` to allow people to change the behaviour via an override?
Good point, but this patch I intended to be a bugfix - one that needs to be backported quick & easily to the stable branches.
Note there is a patch from Will to expose Prometheus server externally: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/828695

deployment/keystone/keystone-container-p.message: How was this working? If these interfaces are never used by anyone, why have these? It just makes the THT unreadable.

These are used to tune cron jobs (we have the same set of interfaces for all cron jobs)


It seems puppet is converting the list and is currently putting 'valid' configuration but we better fix the incorrect type as we don't really able to accept list with multiple elements.

https://0887da1acd77fe362fe6-dafd5ea511e702465bad7043bbe0ffd9.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/855156/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-9-scenario001-standalone/14a316d/logs/undercloud/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/keystone/var/spool/cron/keystone

Well, I know that we've added that interface everywhere. My question is how is puppet converting those lists to string.

Also, what I'm saying we don't so many parameters with that granularity (I doubt anyone would configure that way). Size of templates have impact on performance.

> Well, I know that we've added that interface everywhere. My question is how is puppet converting those lists to string.


These is a logic within cron provider which converts a list to a string.

https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-cron_core/blob/main/lib/puppet/provider/cron/crontab.rb#L68-L70

This was added to allow usage of array(eg, [1, 31]) which is rendered as a comma-separated strings (eg 1,31).
Usage of array/list might be valid according to the current implementation of the cron provider but this is inconsistent with the parameters for the other cron jobs so we'd better fix the inconsistency.

> Also, what I'm saying we don't so many parameters with that granularity (I doubt anyone would configure that way). Size of templates have impact on performance.

Maybe we should consider deprecate these or even remove these in master ? Even if we do not provide the parameters users can still change these by ExtraConfig. I agree providing native tht interface is not much beneficial.

tox.ini.message: Why are you removing charm-proof here?

Ah, it throws an error like:

    W: actions.$action_name: actions/$action_name does not exist

If we unlink the `change-osd-weight` from the actions directory, then charm-proof will not find it there and complain. I don't think we can leave it there, as it would conflict with the entry point in the charm class, though.

So I can add this feature in cycle highlights.

This will partially solve issues we have e.g. with Ansible module openstack.cloud.project_info [1]. There we could pass any project attribute or an JMESPath expression as filters argument to search_projects() [2] in the past, while doing so with the new search_projects() [3] would fail because it would try to use the contents of filters as query parameters but then might fail because the contents is a JMESPath or an project attribute which is not a valid query argument for OpenStack API [3].

This patch would solve the issue of invalid query arguments. It still requires us to change our code to check whether filters is a JMESPath and if it is, then we would have to convert it to jmespath_filters argument. Which is totally fine, so +1 from me.

ok, it took me a while to understand it, but it's fine. It uses recursion and only one level of recursion is allowed, right?

Not exactly. The idea is to "remove" external brackets. E.g. in ((1)(2)(3(4))) we will do the following recursion:
1. ((1)(2)(3(4)))
2. (1)(2)(3(4))
3. 1
4. 2
5. 3(4)
6. 4

The arg is annoying but it does affect the outcome, just not in the cases you chose, which you could only choose by already knowing the outcome.

I can't see a way to reliably infer the root account from the shard's account, given that (AFAICT) the shards account prefix can be arbitrary. It's actually the auto account prefix that is configurable (with default '.'); the 'shards_' part is hard-coded. And frustratingly a configurable auto account prefix has been deprecated for a long time but still supported. 

Even more frustratingly, past us has cursed us with allowing stupid choices like the auto account prefix being .shards_ i.e. shard account names like .shards_shards_foo are possible. So we can't just search for the first occurrence of the 'shards_'. I *wish* that was not so!

So I think we're left with a style debate between:

1. passing the prefix into the method as a required arg
2. making it a required attribute of ShardRange (annoying because it's effectively deprecated)
3. unbinding the is_child_of method to a module function is_parent_child(shard1, shard2, prefix)

I don't *like* any of the options.

I admit I did not consider option 2 before. If we make the prefix a member of ShardRange what do we do about the signature of make_path? We'd either need to change the definition of that public interface or ignore the prefix member that we added to ShardRange (because the account passed to make_path already has a prefix).

I did consider 3 but preferred the is_child_of semantic of 1. Making it a bound method avoids confusion about which arg is parent and which is child in a module method. Plus we already pass the prefix (albeit as part of the account name) to ShardRange.make_path.

"be used" is equivalent to "tiempo presente en modo subjuntivo" in Spanish: "... requiere que un address scope de IPv6 sea usado para asegurar ...".

"is used" ("es usado") corresponds to "tiempo presente en modo indicativo", which wouldn't be correct in this sentence in Spanish

I found the method name confusing - at first I thought it was going to yield node dicts without the index keys.

I think it at least needs a docstring that clarifies what indexes refers to: it's yielding nodes that don't match brain nodes with given indexes. The indexes are actually the concern of the brain, so maybe it should be a method of brain??

Or, how about changing the method name and signature to make it a bit more explicit:

  def filter_nodes(nodes, exclude_nodes):
      for node in nodes:
          # we ignore the index key when comparing nodes because index
          # varies with the partition for which the nodes were generated
          match_node = {k: mock.ANY if k == 'index' else v
                        for k, v in node.items()}
          if any(n == match_node for n in exclude_nodes):
              continue
          yield node
          
That ^^ would of course be a module function!

It has the advantage of being more flexible (e.g. if we ever want to exclude a shard node from a list of brain nodes).

kernel-rt/debian/deb_patches/0017-debian.message:
I have no problem with the change and applaud the initiative and improvement. I am just curious if we should consider (or if it is possible) to reuse the parrallelism value that recently was added to the build.

I assume that since you are running full builds this is already getting tested in an K8s environment where the cgroup might be restricting the # cpus and that no issues were seen indicates this is being handled just fine in this scenario.

Hi Mark,

Implementing the CPU limit feature turned out to be more challenging than originally thought, because build-pkgs calls dpkg-buildpackages as follows for source package builds:

  dpkg-buildpackage -nc -us -uc -S -d
  
Note the lack of a --jobs or --jobs-try argument.

I have prepared a commit that makes use of the --jobs-try argument for all source package builds. This ensures that make is *not* parallelized via MAKEFLAGS=-jX, but the DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS="... parallel=X ..." make variable is populated with the "parallel=X" option, which I made the kernel build use to set the number of CPUs for xz. Please see: https://manpages.debian.org/bullseye/dpkg-dev/dpkg-buildpackage.1.en.html#J

The catch with this approach is that I need to test a full build from scratch, as one cannot easily determine if there are any packages that make use of the DEB_BUILD_OPTIONS="parallel=X" argument blindly to parallelize make when building source packages.

All this to say, with some further work, I should be able to update this commit and publish another one in the starlingx/root repository, so that the number of CPUs utilized by xz is limited by build-pkgs' --max_make_jobs option.

If what I describe above is an overkill to resolve this issue, please let me know though.
Let's run with your original change and play things by ear if anything falls out and forces a rethink.

Got it. Thank you, Mark.

For what it is worth, my test build (from scratch) that I had started last night (with the aforementioned unpublished changes) finished successfully. If we receive a request to limit the number of CPUs used by xz for compression, I can definitely publish an update to this commit.

Hi Mark,

I am waiting for your feedback.

Thank you,

Vefa

I am easy either way. I think the workload is momentary and would result in an immediate decrease in build times, something that has been marked as high priority. So I am OK giving this a WF+1 and seeing if there is any negative impact.

If adding the max limiter can be done in hours, not days, then I would suggest it be added to this current work.

Sounds good. I will add the number-of-CPUs-limit functionality to this commit.

Thank you.

Hi Mark,

I have been testing this in a 12-CPU build VM, but I assign all of the CPUs to the Kubernetes environment used for my builds, so, to be honest, I do not know if (for example) assigning only 8 CPUs to the build environment would result in xz making use of only 8 CPUs. I can test this.

In case the test mentioned above does not have a positive result (i.e., xz makes use of my VM's 12 CPUs despite the build pods being assigned only 8 CPUs), then it should also be possible to use the pre-existing "build-pkgs" option named "--max_make_jobs", which currently defaults to 6 CPUs. build-pkgs passes the -j6 option to sbuild, which then passes it to dpkg-buildpackage, which ought to pass it to the Makefile snippet being modified in this patch.

All this to say, I can investigate this if you think it would be worthwhile. Please let me know.

Thank you,

Vefa

Hi again,

I confirmed that the build system does not limit the build pods' CPU resources, and hence xz continued to use 12 CPUs even after I restarted minikube with an assignment of 8 CPUs to the build system.

I have confirmed this two ways:

On the build host (i.e., outside of the build container), the following command returns an empty Kubernetes pod resource restriction dictionary:

```
$ kubectl get pod -o json stx-deb-bld-1-stx-pkgbuilder-5d46455f94-r7jm8 | jq '.spec.containers[].resources'

{}
```

According to the documentation at https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/assign-cpu-resource/ the resources dictionary should have a "cpus" entry to limit the number of CPUs assigned to the pod.

Similarly, if I run xz in the "pkgbuilder" container with garbage/placeholder input, I notice that xz makes use of all 12 CPUs:

```
$ stx shell --container pkgbuilder -c 'cat /localdisk/loadbuild/user/stx-deb-bld-1/std/linux/*.tar.gz | xz -vv --threads=0 -c >/dev/null'
xz: Filter chain: --lzma2=dict=8MiB,lc=3,lp=0,pb=2,mode=normal,nice=64,mf=bt4,depth=0
xz: Using up to 12 threads.
xz: 1982 MiB of memory is required. The limiter is disabled.
xz: Decompression will need 9 MiB of memory.
  --- %         42.0 MiB / 43.0 MiB = 0.977    14 MiB/s       0:03             
command terminated with exit code 130
```

All this to say, if we would like to limit the number of CPUs that xz can use, we need to make use of the value of build-pkgs' --max_make_jobs argument.

Mark, should I go ahead with that approach?

> Actually the current implementation internally generates an environment file with the given hieradata and that method is effectively same.

I know that.. What I'm saying is I don't see any need to deprecate this which was intended as an option to use just a bunch of hieradata in a file.

We can still customize the hieradata by defining ExtraConfig in custom env file. Actually the current implementation internally generates an environment file with the given hieradata and that method is effectively same.

Because now we use the same template mechanism to manage configuration for both undercloud/overcloud, template parameters managed by environment files should be a primary option. Exposing another lower level interface would be just redundant and confusing.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This is actual backport (the same change id is used). Why do we need this tag ?

It's clear this is not a clean backport based on the Conflict: tag in the commit message. It does not prevent you from using the usual cherry-pick approach WITHOUT any additional tagging. Resolving conflicts is what we usualy need during backport.

In case you think just listing files with conflicts is not enough then you can explain what was adjusted during bacport by adding additional notes to commit message, as is done in multiple patches like;

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-manila/+/855561

If you really mark this as wallaby-only tag then this should NOT be a backport(should use a different change id). However this and the original master fix the same problem, making this as a simple cherry-pick makes more sense to me.

It may be an overkill, but I had two reasons in mind.

1. I don't want this to get any further. Services were removed in wallaby, so this is the furthest we should backport imho.

2. The merge conflict required manual resolution so it's not a clean cherry pick. If one were to try to use this on, for example, train it might need more adjustment. That would turn it into a different patch still.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Digging into it more, I think we want to support the absolute-form URI -- Clay's got a test to exercise it now (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/856329), and it passes against AWS. And from the RFC (https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7230#section-5.3.2):

   To allow for transition to the absolute-form for all requests in some
   future version of HTTP, a server MUST accept the absolute-form in
   requests, even though HTTP/1.1 clients will only send them in
   requests to proxies.

I pushed up https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/856327 to do the translation super-early -- think you'd have a chance to try it out/review it?

There is a few unit tests aimed at verifying the behavior of the proxy with "on the wire" clients:

https://github.com/NVIDIA/swift/blob/master/test/unit/proxy/test_server.py#L2703

I couldn't find one that attempts to send eventlet.wsgi and the swift API an absolute URI.  I wouldn't be surprised at all if it doesn't work - but my reading of what I think is the current RFC says we should try to make it work?

I'm not sure how s3 responds either - if they return 400 then this might be perfect!  But if they DO allow clients to send absolute-uir (which might explain why there was a client doing it) - maybe we should start thinking about how we're going to support it!?  (It may be reasonable to return 4xx in the interm as long as swift requests don't have any behavior change)

I'm concnered the problem migth be bigger than described and the proposed fix is just plugging one of many holes?  I like *not throwing stack* in principle tho ;)

yeah!

well, maybe... so the swift API it seems returns 404 - https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/852772/1 - better than a traceback! 
 I'm not sure the implications WRT correctness, but my lp bug search makes it look like no one has complained (yet?!)

The only remaining question I have is: what does s3 do when a client sends the absolute uri in the request line?  If people use s3 behind a forward proxy (like inside a corp network with HTTP_PROXY=http://corp-proxy.example.com) it may have to support absolute uris (or maybe the proxy has to transform the request and strip them).

I was not aware that absolute URIs were accepted here.
Maybe we should do something like this instead of denying the request?

```
diff --git a/swift/common/utils.py b/swift/common/utils.py
index ab6615a4c..7dcf66a0b 100644
--- a/swift/common/utils.py
+++ b/swift/common/utils.py
@@ -1634,7 +1634,8 @@ def link_fd_to_path(fd, target_path, dirs_created=0, retries=2, fsync=True):
             dirpath = os.path.dirname(dirpath)
 
 
-def split_path(path, minsegs=1, maxsegs=None, rest_with_last=False):
+def split_path(path, minsegs=1, maxsegs=None, rest_with_last=False,
+               allow_absolute_uri=False):
     """
     Validate and split the given HTTP request path.
 
@@ -1655,6 +1656,10 @@ def split_path(path, minsegs=1, maxsegs=None, rest_with_last=False):
               segments will return as None)
     :raises ValueError: if given an invalid path
     """
+    if allow_absolute_uri:
+        # We are only interested in the path part.
+        # Safe if there is no scheme.
+        path = urlparse(path).path
     if not maxsegs:
         maxsegs = minsegs
     if minsegs > maxsegs:
```

I've seen some clients/SDKs do this before: there's https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/issues/944 and I seem to recall seeing some old versions of rclone that would send absolute-uris (though maybe it was just using the golang SDK).

I still haven't tested it against AWS, but it seems likely that they'd accept it. Probably a good candidate for something in the test/s3api/ tree, particularly now that those are run in the gate as an additional set of func tests.

I know we have existing entries that use this format, but most of the file does not.  I will defer to the build team, but I think that in general we do not want to explicitly add the snapshot URL to this file unless we have to. 
(I am fairly sure I should have cleaned up the tzdata entry when I updated it recently)

If we are concerned that this will change frequently, using the snapshot is OK, since it protects us from churn

downloader should currently find this package in its existing list of repos without requiring the extra snapshot URL

libfreetype6  2.10.4+dfsg-1+deb11u1

I made this change locally, and I was able to run downloader
2022-08-19 14:42:11,302 - downloader - DEBUG: package libfreetype6_2.10.4+dfsg-1+deb11u1 needs to be downloaded
2022-08-19 14:42:11,437 - downloader - INFO: libfreetype6_2.10.4+dfsg-1+deb11u1 download ok

Yes, you're correct. Normally, we don't set URL for adding new package, and should find the candidate from snapshot, but this case is to get the newest version from Debian upstream to fix a CVE. We have to add the url, otherwise, once Debian upstream updates the version in the future, downloader will fails. This is the reason we support addition url for some cases.

puppet-manifests/debian/deb_folder/rules.message:
how is this erb file created in this location?
"/usr/share/puppet/modules/platform/templates/" is its deployment path. Why do we need to remove it like this?. I see the file also in "config/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/templates/nslcd.conf.erb"

In a current deployment I am seeing also these 2 other nslcd files

./usr/share/augeas/lenses/dist/nslcd.aug
./usr/share/puppet/modules.available/puppet-nslcd/templates/nslcd.erb

Will you also remove these ones?

/usr/share/puppet/modules.available/puppet-nslcd/templates/nslcd.erb is from puppet-nslcd. It is removed already:

[root@controller-0 ldap(keystone_admin)]# ls /usr/share/puppet/modules.available/puppet-nslcd/templates/nslcd.erb
ls: cannot access '/usr/share/puppet/modules.available/puppet-nslcd/templates/nslcd.erb': No such file or directory

I can take a look at /usr/share/augeas/lenses/dist/nslcd.aug.

No, /usr/share/augeas/lenses/dist/nslcd.aug is from augeas-lenses package, which is a generic package containing many .aug files. And it's a binary package, so we can't patch it to just remove nslcd.aug.

In the rules file:
        $(MAKE) install hiera_v5=true ignore_puppet_warnings=true \
                BINDIR=$(CURDIR)/debian/tmp/usr/local/bin \
                CONFIGDIR=$(CURDIR)/debian/tmp/etc/puppet \
                MODULEDIR=$(CURDIR)/debian/tmp/usr/share/puppet/modules

will put nslcd.conf.erb in $(CURDIR)/debian/tmp/usr/share/puppet/modules, then in 
the install file:
usr/share/puppet/*

will install everything in $(CURDIR)/debian/tmp/usr/share/puppet/modules to /usr/share/puppet/modules, including the nslcd.conf.erb.

So we can remove it after the "make" in the rules file.

We can't remove the nslcd.conf.erb from the source, because CentOS still need it.
